articles.headline: Picking Stocks After Facebook
articles.snippet: Buying an individual company’s stock is a wager on an unknowable future, as Facebook investors will tell you, and it can take decades before you know if you have a winner.
articles.abstract: Buying an individual company’s stock is a wager on an unknowable future, as Facebook investors will tell you, and it can take decades before you know if you have a winner.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been hard not to gawk these last two weeks at Facebook’s unruly initial public offering and its declining share price. Any spectacle like this practically dares you not to stare.

articles.headline: G.M. Plans Big Buyouts for Retirees in Pension
articles.snippet: General Motors will seek to cut $26 billion in pension obligations through changes in payments to retired white-collar workers.
articles.abstract: General Motors will seek to cut $26 billion in pension obligations through changes in payments to retired white-collar workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors said Friday that it would offer lump-sum payments to thousands of white-collar retirees to reduce its pension obligations, which are the biggest in the nation, and would pay Prudential Insurance to take over its pension payments to other retirees.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Jobs Report Makes Federal Reserve More Likely to Act
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials are reluctant to provide further stimulus, but the slowing rate of job creation suggests they have not done enough.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials are reluctant to provide further stimulus, but the slowing rate of job creation suggests they have not done enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The odds surely increased Friday that the Federal Reserve will ride again to the rescue of the faltering economic recovery, making borrowing a little cheaper for a little longer, as it has done repeatedly over the last four years.

articles.headline: Slowdown in Growth Could Reshape Fight for Presidency
articles.snippet: Friday’s weak employment report was a potential turning point, focusing new attention on the economic implications of the partisan standoff over tax and spending policy.
articles.abstract: Friday’s weak employment report was a potential turning point, focusing new attention on the economic implications of the partisan standoff over tax and spending policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The weak employment report on Friday held the potential to reshape the presidential campaign, members of both parties said, lifting Mitt Romney’s efforts to make the race all about President Obama’s handling of the economy and making it harder for Democrats to break through in their efforts to define Mr. Romney on their terms.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Mark Landler

articles.headline: New Rules for Money Transfers, but Few Limits
articles.snippet: Money-transfer companies like Western Union largely escaped the regulatory crackdown in the wake of the financial crisis, but soon they will be subject to new federal rules.
articles.abstract: Money-transfer companies like Western Union largely escaped the regulatory crackdown in the wake of the financial crisis, but soon they will be subject to new federal rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: From her job at a packaging factory in Chicago, Patricia Gonzalez cobbles together $70 a month to send to her mother in Guadalajara, Mexico, leaving her less money for groceries. In Boardman, Ore., Raul Esparza, a migrant farmworker, works as many hours as he can to send $50 a week to his children in Mexico City.

articles.headline: Rape Case, in Public, Cites Abuse by Armed Groups in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: An Afghan family’s official complaint about the rape of an 18-year-old girl is a test of the government’s willingness to challenge armed militias.
articles.abstract: An Afghan family’s official complaint about the rape of an 18-year-old girl is a test of the government’s willingness to challenge armed militias.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Lal Bibi is an 18-year-old rape victim who has taken a step rarely seen in Afghanistan: she has spoken out publicly against her tormentors, local militiamen, including several who have been identified as members of the American-trained Afghan Local Police.

articles.headline: New Turmoil in Egypt Greets Mixed Verdict for Mubarak
articles.snippet: Lawyers said former President Hosni Mubarak’s life sentence as an accessory in the killing of unarmed protesters was vulnerable to appeal, and charges of corruption were dismissed.
articles.abstract: Lawyers said former President Hosni Mubarak’s life sentence as an accessory in the killing of unarmed protesters was vulnerable to appeal, and charges of corruption were dismissed.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian court on Saturday sentenced former President Hosni Mubarak to life in prison as an accomplice in the killing of unarmed demonstrators during the protests that ended his nearly 30-year rule.

articles.headline: It’s Not Billions, but It Can Help Rescue an Artist
articles.snippet: A number of small, private rescue funds have been lending a hand to a group that is definitely not in the too-big-to-fail camp: writers, artists and other creative types.
articles.abstract: A number of small, private rescue funds have been lending a hand to a group that is definitely not in the too-big-to-fail camp: writers, artists and other creative types.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHERE’S my bailout?

articles.headline: Lawsuit Shakes Foundation of a Man’s World of Tech
articles.snippet: A sexual discrimination lawsuit by Ellen Pao at the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins has prompted wider discussion about the treatment of women in the tech world.
articles.abstract: A sexual discrimination lawsuit by Ellen Pao at the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins has prompted wider discussion about the treatment of women in the tech world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Palo Alto, Calif.

articles.headline: The Curtain Opens on 401(k) Fees
articles.snippet: New rules will require fuller disclosure about fees in retirement accounts. And that could mean an unpleasant surprise when investors open their statements this fall.
articles.abstract: New rules will require fuller disclosure about fees in retirement accounts. And that could mean an unpleasant surprise when investors open their statements this fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF recent stock market gyrations have taken a bite out of your 401(k), get ready for more discomfort. You’re about to learn how much you’re paying just to maintain that account.

articles.headline: Pain Pills Add Cost and Delays to Job Injuries
articles.snippet: Narcotic painkillers, which can mask rather than treat pain, can increase disability payouts and expenses by delaying an employee’s return to work.
articles.abstract: Narcotic painkillers, which can mask rather than treat pain, can increase disability payouts and expenses by delaying an employee’s return to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Workplace insurers are accustomed to making billions of dollars in payments each year, with the biggest sums going to employees hurt in major accidents, like those mangled by machines or crushed in building collapses.

articles.headline: In Economic Deluge, a World That Can’t Bail Together
articles.snippet: In 2008, major countries managed to come together on a coordinated course that averted a global depression. They seem unwilling to cooperate again.
articles.abstract: In 2008, major countries managed to come together on a coordinated course that averted a global depression. They seem unwilling to cooperate again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than four years ago, with the world’s financial system in danger of collapsing, major countries managed to come together on a coordinated course that averted a global depression.

articles.headline: Oil Output Soars as Iraq Retools, Easing Shaky Markets
articles.snippet: Analysts say an Iraqi boom should cushion oil markets from price spikes and offer relief for the West as it tightens sanctions on Iran.
articles.abstract: Analysts say an Iraqi boom should cushion oil markets from price spikes and offer relief for the West as it tightens sanctions on Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Despite sectarian bombings and political gridlock, Iraq’s crude oil production is soaring, providing a singular bright spot for the nation’s future and relief for global oil markets as the West tightens sanctions on Iranian exports.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Candidates Have College, Spicy Chicken and ‘Star Trek’ in Common
articles.snippet: Friends and colleagues say Mitt Romney and President Obama share personality, leadership and decision-making styles.
articles.abstract: Friends and colleagues say Mitt Romney and President Obama share personality, leadership and decision-making styles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Points of unity: Mitt Romney and President Obama both like process-driven decisions, iPads, ABC’s “Modern Family” and chicken.

articles.headline: Euro Zone Is Lurching to a Crossroad
articles.snippet: The economic crisis in Europe is becoming an existential one for the monetary union, officials say, unless governments act to solidify the alliance.
articles.abstract: The economic crisis in Europe is becoming an existential one for the monetary union, officials say, unless governments act to solidify the alliance.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Spain’s economic crisis deepens and uncertainty swirls over Greece’s future in the euro zone, the guardians of the increasingly fragile European monetary union are near a moment of truth: can they muster the will and resources to keep the euro zone from breaking apart?

articles.headline: A $1 Cigarette Tax Starts a $47 Million Brawl in California
articles.snippet: Health groups are pushing a ballot initiative to impose a $1-a-pack tax, provoking a storm of advertisements to defeat the biggest threat the industry has faced in the state in a decade.
articles.abstract: Health groups are pushing a ballot initiative to impose a $1-a-pack tax, provoking a storm of advertisements to defeat the biggest threat the industry has faced in the state in a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — California has some of the toughest antismoking laws in the country — it is illegal, in some places, to smoke in your own apartment — and boasts the second-lowest per capita smoking rate in the 50 states. But for all the disdain toward smoking, it has been 14 years since California raised its cigarette tax, a tribute to the power of the tobacco industry here and the waning of this state’s antitobacco dominance.

articles.headline: New Tabloid by Murdoch Losing Sales
articles.snippet: Sales of the Sunday edition of The Sun, a brash daily tabloid, have fallen 28 percent since it first hit newsstands in February.
articles.abstract: Sales of the Sunday edition of The Sun, a brash daily tabloid, have fallen 28 percent since it first hit newsstands in February.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rupert Murdoch has endured a litany of blows in the unending phone-hacking scandal at his British tabloids. But one setback isn’t happening in Parliament, but on Britain’s newsstands.

articles.headline: Newspapers Cut Days From Publishing Week
articles.snippet: Some daily newspapers are cutting printing and delivery schedules and shifting their emphasis to the Web, but industry analysts warned that such moves might alienate once-loyal readers.
articles.abstract: Some daily newspapers are cutting printing and delivery schedules and shifting their emphasis to the Web, but industry analysts warned that such moves might alienate once-loyal readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The news waits for no one. But newspapers might start asking readers to — at least for print copies.

articles.headline: Expert Issues a Cyberwar Warning
articles.snippet: Eugene Kaspersky says his discovery of the Flame virus adds weight to his warnings of the grave dangers posed by governments that manufacture and release viruses on the Internet.
articles.abstract: Eugene Kaspersky says his discovery of the Flame virus adds weight to his warnings of the grave dangers posed by governments that manufacture and release viruses on the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When Eugene Kaspersky, the founder of Europe’s largest antivirus company, discovered the Flame virus that is afflicting computers in Iran and the Middle East, he recognized it as a technologically sophisticated virus that only a government could create.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Brash Chef and Big Bet for CNN
articles.snippet: CNN Worldwide, suffering poor ratings, is taking a chance on Anthony Bourdain’s cocky persona with a new travel-and-food show.
articles.abstract: CNN Worldwide, suffering poor ratings, is taking a chance on Anthony Bourdain’s cocky persona with a new travel-and-food show.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael K. Williams played Omar Little, the righteous stickup man in “The Wire,” and now plays Chalky White, the bootlegger on “Boardwalk Empire,” so he is a big deal in the Brooklyn housing projects where he grew up. Standing in Gloria’s 3, a Trinidadian restaurant in nearby Crown Heights last Thursday, he said he had fun running around his old neighborhood. But he added that it was the man he was with who created most of the fuss.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Was Warned About Lax Risk Controls
articles.snippet: Bank officials are expected to belatedly follow the recommendation of a group of shareholder advocates to strengthen the board committee that oversees risk.
articles.abstract: Bank officials are expected to belatedly follow the recommendation of a group of shareholder advocates to strengthen the board committee that oversees risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: A small group of shareholder advocates delivered an urgent message to top executives at JPMorgan Chase more than a year ago: the bank’s risk controls needed to be improved.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Merrill Losses Were Withheld Before Bank of America Deal
articles.snippet: Days before shareholders voted on Bank of America’s 2008 purchase of Merrill Lynch, top executives were told the investment firm’s losses would most likely hammer future earnings.
articles.abstract: Days before shareholders voted on Bank of America’s 2008 purchase of Merrill Lynch, top executives were told the investment firm’s losses would most likely hammer future earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Days before Bank of America shareholders approved the bank’s $50 billion purchase of Merrill Lynch in December 2008, top bank executives were advised that losses at the investment firm would most likely hammer the combined companies’ earnings in the years to come. But shareholders were not told about the looming losses, which would prompt a second taxpayer bailout of $20 billion, leaving them instead to rely on rosier projections from the bank that the deal would make money relatively soon after it was completed.

articles.headline: Intrigue in Karzai Family as an Afghan Era Closes
articles.snippet: As Hamid Karzai’s days as Afghanistan’s president draw to a close, his family members are trying to protect their status while secretly fighting among themselves over the fortune they have amassed.
articles.abstract: As Hamid Karzai’s days as Afghanistan’s president draw to a close, his family members are trying to protect their status while secretly fighting among themselves over the fortune they have amassed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the end in sight for Hamid Karzai’s days in office as Afghanistan’s president, members of his family are trying to protect their status, weighing how to hold on to power while secretly fighting among themselves for control of the fortune they have amassed in the last decade.

articles.headline: Food Trucks in Paris? U.S. Cuisine Finds Open Minds, and Mouths
articles.snippet: Artisanal food trucks have been making inroads in Paris, adding a new twist in culinary culture to a city where diners rarely eat on the go, much less with their hands.
articles.abstract: Artisanal food trucks have been making inroads in Paris, adding a new twist in culinary culture to a city where diners rarely eat on the go, much less with their hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — An artisanal taco truck has come to Paris. The Cantine California started parking here in April, the latest in a recent American culinary invasion that includes chefs at top restaurants; trendy menu items like cheesecake, bagels and bloody Marys; and notions like chalking the names of farmers on the walls of restaurants.

articles.headline: Chesapeake Agrees to Revamp Its Board
articles.snippet: Chesapeake Energy, in an effort to quell an open revolt by shareholders angry about high executive compensation and poor corporate oversight, said it would replace four current board members with new outside directors.
articles.abstract: Chesapeake Energy, in an effort to quell an open revolt by shareholders angry about high executive compensation and poor corporate oversight, said it would replace four current board members with new outside directors.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Chesapeake Energy and its beleaguered chief executive, Aubrey K. McClendon, executed another strategic retreat on Monday.
